abstract.p: Harry Hess letter on Frank Kermode's April 23 essay on heaven recalls William James's rejection of 'middle-class paradise' and Orson Welles' radio sketch2

block.p: Frank Kermode's essay ''Heaven, They're in Heaven'' (April 23) reminded me of an amusing aphorism: ''Heaven for climate and hell for company.'' And William James's rejecting a ''middle-class paradise'' to escape the ''atrocious harmlessness of all things'' put me in mind of Orson Welles. On his radio show, he did a sketch in which a man becomes so bored with the endless pleasures of heaven that he asks to be sent to hell and receives the reply, ''You are in hell.''
